This report was prepared by V. de Wit, senior health specialist (South Asia Department Social 
Services Division); J. Mahmood; and S. Solter.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of Bangladesh (the Government) and the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB)  are  currently  implementing  the  Urban  Primary  Health  Care  Project  (UPHCP).1  This 
Project, implemented through the Local Government Division (LGD) and 4 city corporations 
(CCs), supports contracting of nongovernment organizations (NGOs) to provide urban health 
services for the poor. The Project is coming to a close in December 2004, and the Government 
has requested for a second phase to consolidate achievements and expand to new urban 
populations.2  The ADB Fact-Finding Mission visited Bangladesh on 9–19 June 2003 to review 
the sector, assess the UPHCP, identify lessons learned, consult stakeholders, and plan project 
preparatory technical assistance (TA)3 for the proposed second UPHCP. In a wrap-up meeting 
on 18 June 2003, ADB and the Government reached an understanding on the objectives, 
scope,  implementation  arrangements,  cost  estimates  and  financing  plan,  and  consulting 
services of the TA. The project framework is in Appendix 1.    
     
II.     ISSUES 
2.  General. Bangladesh’s population is estimated at 132 million people. About 30 million 
live in urban areas, including 6 CCs and about 250 municipalities. Due to rural-urban migration, 
urban populations are increasing at the rate of about 6% per year. While the average per capita 
income is about $370 per year, half of both urban and rural populations live in poverty, and 
about half of the poor are very poor.4 The very poor live mostly in slums and squatter areas 
under  harsh  social  and  environmental  conditions.  Despite  significant  gains  over  the  past 
decade, the health, nutrition, and population status of the urban poor is unacceptable. The infant 
mortality rate in urban slums is about 100/1,000 live births, compared to about 80/1,000 live 
births in rural areas. Respiratory infections and diarrhea are common causes of child death. 
About 60% of children below the age of 5 years are underweight, and many lack micronutrients. 
The number of maternal deaths is declining due to increased contraception resulting in reduced 
fertility.5 However, the maternal mortality ratio among pregnant women remains high due to 
early marriage, poor nutrition, and other causes. The summary initial poverty and social analysis 
report form is in Appendix 2. 
 
3.  The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare (MHFW) is responsible for sector policy, 
national priority programs, hospitals, and rural primary health care (PHC).6 MHFW, with support 
of a consortium,7 has been implementing the Health and Population Sector Program for the past 
5 years. MHFW is not satisfied with the performance of the program, but remains supportive of 
the sector-wide approach. It prepared the follow-up Health, Nutrition, and Population Sector 
Program  (HNPSP),  this  time  including  nutrition  and  urban  health  services.  HNPSP  also 
proposes health sector reforms, including contracting out union services to NGOs, developing 
district boards, increasing hospital autonomy, and providing a voucher system for the poor.

2 
4.  As stated in the conceptual framework, responsibility for urban PHC rests with LGD in 
the Ministry of Local Government, Rural Development, and Cooperatives—and the six CCs and 
250 municipalities. In practice, only the CCs and the larger municipalities offer public health 
services.8 Many smaller municipalities lack capacity for managing health services and depend 
on  MHFW.  Limited  availability  of  affordable  urban  PHC  has  caused  congestion  of  tertiary 
hospitals and lack of services for the urban poor. Many poor parents don’t seek treatment or 
they use shops to purchase whatever they can afford.  NGOs and three major external agencies 
have funded urban PHC in the past decade. The NGO Service Delivery Project of the United 
States Agency for International Development is supporting 41 directly selected NGOs, about 
half of them urban, to provide an essential services package (ESP) in their clinics. The Better 
Health for Urban Poor Project of the Department for International Development supports NGO 
services  and  reaches  the  “floating”  poor  through  community  health  workers  (CHWs).  The 
UPHCP follows a different approach, in that the Government contracts NGOs to provide PHC.     
 
5.  The Urban Primary Health Care Project. The UPHCP’s main objective has been to 
improve  health  of  the  urban  poor,  especially  women  and  children.  Its  components  are  (i) 
providing  PHC  through  partnership  agreements  (PAs),  (ii)  strengthening  urban  PHC 
infrastructure, (iii) building capacity of CCs, and (iv) supporting project implementation and 
relevant research. The main component and innovation has been to use government funds to 
contract NGOs, through PAs, to provide ESPs for the poor in defined catchment populations of 
about 300,000 people. Each NGO was allowed to develop its own system to achieve the 
targets. In most cases, a four-tier system has emerged, with a comprehensive reproductive 
health care center, PHC centers (each services about 50,000 people), satellite clinics, and 
CHWs. The monitoring function has been partly contracted out to an independent firm, which 
also conducts baseline and follow-up surveys to assess NGO performance. NGOs were to be 
paid according to their performance, with an additional bonus of up to 6% of the contract 
amount depending on the health impact in the catchment population.    
 
6.  Project implementation was initially delayed due to the policy issues that needed to be 
resolved to allow LGD to take this new role in urban areas, and to the time needed to design 
and implement a competitive and transparent bidding process and provide infrastructure. Of 16 
PAs, 10 are in Dhaka, 3 in Chittagong, 2 in Khulna, and 1 in Rajshahi. Two PAs in Chittagong 
follow another approach, in that the Chittagong CC is the implementing agency rather than an 
NGO.  Because  of  the  delay,  the  project  closing  date  was  extended  by  18  months  to  31 
December 2004. About $10.4 million of the original loan amount was canceled due to savings 
on NGO contracts, medical supplies, and construction, and additional funding from the United 
Nations Populations Fund and national programs for priority diseases.    
 
7.  Many lessons have been learned. Regarding scope, the flexible system design resulted 
in a clinic-oriented approach: NGOs are not automatically focusing on the system that will give 
maximum overall impact, and targets are mortality-oriented. NGO services are mainly focused 
on women, and less so on children and men, reflecting the background of the NGOs. More 
focus is needed on community activities: only a few, sometimes overqualified CHWs were 
deployed. In addition, children will not benefit much unless the environmental conditions are 
improved.    
 
8.  LGD developed a cost-based NGO financing system, reimbursing NGOs each quarter 
for  actual  expenditures  according  to  agreed  prices  and  contract  ceilings.  The  experience                        
                                                 
8   The population of the 6 city corporations (CCs) is about 15 million, and of the 20 largest municipalities about 3 
million.

3 
showed that a performance-based system is difficult to link with NGO effort, as many people 
outside the catchment area use the services, the environmental conditions undermine impact on 
child health, and performance is difficult to measure in time. The competitive bidding process, 
without adequate standardization, created a situation where the NGO budget was too low. 
Another important challenge was to make services affordable for the poor. The very poor are 
given free services using a color-coded card. For the non-poor,9 NGOs are recovering about 
20–50% of their costs through user fees. While this does not provide a financial incentive for the 
NGOs,  as  this  amount  is  deducted  from  the  total  amount  reimbursed  to  NGOs,  it  helps 
overcome the occasional cash flow problems. Another challenge is to sustain services after 
external funding stops. Currently, CCs target only 1% of their budget for health services. 
 
9.  Despite the initial delays, the UPHCP has been highly successful in providing critical 
maternal care and family planning services of good quality (including Caesarian sections), and 
in reducing maternal mortality. Client visits have increased rapidly from 300,000 in 2001 to over 
a million in 2002. A large number of people have been reached through outreach services. CCs, 
NGOs, and beneficiaries are pleased with the services.  
 
10.  Proposal for a New Project. Current services clearly demonstrate that public-private 
partnership has been successful in delivering affordable quality ESP to the urban poor. It is 
important to explore the possibility of making this model fully sustainable by strengthening 
management  and  financing  capacity  in  CCs,  and  expanding  it  to  municipalities.  Such 
strengthening and expansion would need to be firmly rooted in the policy framework of the 
Government’s HNPSP.  
 
11.  The Government, NGOs, and beneficiaries want to improve the current approach and 
explore whether it can be used in municipalities. A first component will support PAs: the 4 
current CCs would be phased out, with CCs taking over financing services for the poor, and 
non-poor services being managed through cost recovery or prepaid arrangements. Two new 
CCs (Sylhet and Barisal) and a number of municipalities could be added, resulting in a modest 
increase of the catchment population. CHWs may be added to reach the very poor. More 
emphasis  is  needed  on  nutrition  interventions,  child  care,  and  male  health  promotion.  An 
improved bidding process will allow hiring more qualified staff and better incentives. The second 
component  will  improve  infrastructure  and  environmental  conditions  in  slums  and  health 
services. The third component will strengthen capacities and linkages of LGD, MHFW, CCs, and 
large municipalities; along with monitoring, evaluation, and operations research. The Project is 
likely to be implemented through LGD, CCs, and selected municipalities, strengthened for this 
purpose and for sustaining health services.    
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Purpose and Output 
 
12.  The purpose of the TA is to evaluate the current UPHCP and design a follow-up project 
that will extend and improve the health, nutrition, and population status of the urban poor, 
particularly women and children, by ensuring that they have access to high-quality, affordable, 
and sustainable PHC services. The TA will also plan to strengthen the capacity and linkages of 
LGD, MHFW, CCs, municipalities, and related institutions.          
   
 
                                                 
9  The targeting of the poor and affordability of services need to be examined.

4 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
13.  The TA will consist of a situation analysis of the urban health sector, and preparation of 
a project proposal following a bottom-up, participatory approach. The situation analysis will 
include review of (i) the UPHCP and other health projects; (ii) the policy, governance, and 
financing environment; and (iii) living conditions that affect health and nutrition.  
 
14.  The TA will review (i) the sector policy framework, and governance and financing plans; 
(ii) institutional capacity, linkages, and coordination; and (iii) NGO capacity building needs, 
monitoring, and supervision, in particular for improving staff incentives, quality of services, and 
access to the very poor. Second, the TA will help develop the project scope, including (i) the 
four-tier system, ESP, and expansion into nutrition and water and sanitation interventions; (ii) 
improved benefits to children; (iii) male health issues; (iv) environmental improvement; and (v) 
more  convenient  and  better  quality  services  and  referral.  Third,  the  TA  will  help  examine 
sources and uses of funds for urban PHC, to determine potential for realigning PHC financing 
and expenditures. This will include examination of CC capacity to finance urban PHC services. 
The TA will include a cost analysis of contracting modalities. The TA will help examine the 
affordability of health services, and will propose cost recovery and pricing improvements. The 
consultants will examine the cost of improving the quality of services, through variations in staff, 
incentives, and  quality  control  measures.  Fourth,  the  TA  will  include  a  poverty  and  social 
analysis of the conditions in urban slums. This will include an assessment of alternative options 
to improve benefits to the very poor, the process for selecting CHWs, and the potential for 
organizing communities to solve environmental problems. It will also assess whether the Project 
will affect any ethnic minorities with special needs, and whether there are resettlement issues. 
Cost recovery schemes and social access to health facilities, including those related to location 
and design of facilities, will also be examined. Fifth, the TA will help review physical planning, 
land acquisition, and facility design in the UPHCP. It will help identify priority populations and 
locations  for  expanding  services  based  on  need,  service  gaps,  and  commitment  of  local 
governments to expand services for the poor. It will include a review of alternative options for 
the provision of facilities and improving the environmental conditions.  
 
15.  Based on the foregoing analysis, the TA will develop (i) a detailed description of a 5 year 
investment project; (ii) policy action to improve and sustain the efficiency and effectiveness of 
the UPHCP model through public-private partnership; (iii) mechanisms for strengthening the 
capacity of the CCs in planning, financing, supervising, monitoring, and evaluating of PHC 
programs;  (iv)  estimates  of  capital  and  recurrent  expenditures;  and  (v)  implementation 
arrangements and schedules, a project performance management system, and a draft project 
         
implementation manual.       
 
C.  Cost and Financing  
 
16.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $500,000 equivalent, comprising $230,000 in 
foreign  exchange  cost  and  $270,000  equivalent  in  local  currency  cost.  ADB  will  provide 
$400,000 equivalent, covering the entire foreign exchange cost and $170,000 equivalent of the 
local currency cost. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special Fund, funded 
by the Government of Japan. The Government will finance the remaining $100,000 equivalent 
of  local  currency  cost,  through  in-kind  contributions  including  counterpart  staff,  field  visits, 
workshops, and office accommodation and utilities. The cost and financing plan are in Appendix 
3. The Government has been advised that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance 
any ensuing project.

5 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
17.  LGD will be the Executing Agency for the TA. A steering committee will be established, 
to  be  chaired  by  the  secretary,  LGD,  and  including  representatives  of  MHFW,  Economic 
Relations  Department,  the  Planning  Commission,  CCs,  municipalities,  NGOs,  development 
partners, and civil society. The steering committee will guide and coordinate the TA through 
monthly meetings. A project coordination unit (PCU) will be established in LGD. The PCU will be 
responsible for coordinating the TA, including liaison with stakeholders; data collection and 
analysis; support of consultants; provision of logistic support; and organization of workshops. 
The PCU will comprise a full-time senior planning officer (head), two counterparts, and two 
assistants. The PCU will be supported by other planning officers of LGD and CCs on a part-time 
basis. A participatory planning process will be followed, starting from the community level and 
NGO partners to formulate the initial proposal.           
 
18.  A total of 21 person-months of consulting services will be made available. The two 
international  consultants  will  include  a  team  leader  and  expert  in  health  planning  and 
management (4 person-months), and governance expert (3 person-months). The five national 
consultants will include a health economist (4 person-months), a sociologist (2 person-months), 
a nutrition specialist (2 person-months), a capacity building expert (3 person-months), and an 
infrastructure planner (3 person-months). All consultants will be selected and engaged through 
a  firm,  following  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of  Consultants,  and  other  arrangements 
satisfactory  to  ADB  on  the  engagement  of  domestic  consultants.  The  simplified  technical 
proposal format and the quality and cost-based selection method will be used. The indicative 
terms of reference are in Appendix 4. An observer from the Government will be invited to Manila 
for contract negotiations. Minor equipment and office supplies, including computers, printer, 
facsimile  machine,  photocopy  machine,  software  and  Internet  connection,  furniture,  and 
airconditioners  will  be  procured  under  the  TA  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  for 
Procurement. All equipment purchased under the TA will be handed over to the Government 
after TA completion.  
19.  Within 2 weeks of the start of the TA, the PCU will submit an inception report discussing 
the methodology of the TA and initial findings. The sector analysis will be submitted within 2 
months after the start of the TA, followed by a draft final report 2 weeks before completion of the 
TA, and the final report within 2 weeks after completion of the TA, for approval of the LGD and  
ADB. The TA will start in October 2003 and will be completed by April 2004.    
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
20.    The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $400,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Bangladesh for preparing the Second Urban Primary Health Care Project, 
and hereby reports this action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  International Consultants 
 
1.  Urban Health Planning and Management Specialist and Team Leader  
(4 person-months) 
 
1.  The team leader will be a senior public health specialist with experience in urban primary 
health care (PHC), health sector reform, contracting out of health services, and preparation of 
project  proposals  as  a  team  leader.  The  team  leader  will  be  the  primary  liaison  with  the 
Government of Bangladesh including the Local Government Division (LGD), the Ministry of 
Health and Family Welfare (MHFW), city corporations (CCs), municipalities, nongovernment 
organizations (NGOs), and partner agencies. The team leader will organize and oversee the 
work and reports of the other consultants, with a focus on project planning, and be responsible 
for the following:  
 
(i)  With the team and stakeholders, review the context of the Urban Primary Health 
Care  Project  (UPHCP),  including  needs,  governance,  capacity,  policies,  and 
programs; and ensure that key issues are adequately addressed in the design. 
(ii)  Describe the role of development partners and NGOs, identify possible roles of 
Asian Development Bank (ADB), and improve the plan for ADB in the sector. 
(iii)  Evaluate the first UPHCP with other team members, including an assessment of 
the performance, cost and financing, affordability, quality, and public perception 
of services. 
(iv)  Prepare a detailed proposal for the second UPHCP with clearly defined project 
framework,  components,  implementation  arrangements,  implementation 
schedule, and performance management system. 
(v)  Propose policy actions required for successful implementation of the second 
UPHCP, and sustainability of urban PHC. 
(vi)  Work with the health economist in preparing the project cost estimates. 
(vii)  Formulate  the  terms  of  reference  (TOR)  and  qualifications  for  consultants, 
counterparts, and long-term advisers for the UPHCP. 
(viii)  Prepare  a  written  report  in  response  to  these  TOR,  including  a  final  report 
resembling  a  report  and  recommendation  of  the  president  to  the  board  of 
directors that incorporates the other consultants’ reports. 
 
2.  Governance Specialist (3 person-months)  
 
2.  The governance specialist will have had at least 10 years of experience in public sector 
governance and contracting and, together with the capacity building specialist, will concentrate 
on developing the policy framework and institutional capacity of local governments to develop 
PHC within their jurisdictions. The consultant will have the following responsibilities: 
 
(i)  Provide a general overview of the organization, administration, and financing of 
public  and  private  health  services  in  urban  and  rural  areas,  with  particular 
reference to urban PHC in CCs and municipalities. 
(ii)  Assist the team leader in reviewing policies and plans for the health sector to 
determine the parameters for project design and the role for ADB.

(iii)  Identify key governance issues in CCs and large municipalities and determine 
appropriate arrangements under the second UPHCP so that local governance is 
supported and strengthened in every way possible.  
(iv)  Assess the experience with performance-based contracting in the first UPHCP 
and other projects, and propose improvements for the second project. 
(v)  With MHFW and LGD, develop a joint approach to governance of urban PHC. 
(vi)  Assess the capabilities of current CCs, municipalities, LGD, MHFW, and NGOs 
regarding urban PHC management, including planning, monitoring, evaluation, 
quality assurance, and use of data. Develop an effective strategy and plan for 
improving the capacity of CCs, municipalities, and LGD, including coordination, 
training, use of technical advisers, and other inputs. 
(vii)  Visit CCs and a number of candidate municipalities to determine which ones can 
make a serious commitment to developing their urban PHC.  
(viii)  Prepare  procurement  packages  in  line  with  the  Guidelines  for  Procurement 
Under ADB Loans.  
(ix)  Prepare  a  draft  project  implementation  memorandum  according  to  ADB’s 
Operations Manual sections 32, 34, and 41. 
(x)  Prepare a written report in response to these TOR. 
 
B.  Domestic Consultants 
3.  Health Economist (4 person-months) 
 
3.  The health economist will have had at least 8 years of experience in the health sector. 
The consultant will focus on project economic and financial analysis, and cost estimates, and be 
responsible for the following:  
 
(i)  Examine  whether  and  what  level  of  user  charges  is  appropriate  for  various 
groups of beneficiaries. Assess financial capacities of beneficiaries and NGOs in 
CCs, large municipalities, and small municipalities. Examine how beneficiaries 
manage catastrophic medical expenses, and suggest what could be done to 
assist  the  poor  in  meeting  these  costs.  Suggest  practical  mechanisms  for 
determining and monitoring user charges on an ongoing basis. 
(ii)  Assess the sources and level of financing of UPHCP and propose a strategy for 
CCs  to  cover  the  costs  of  NGO-provided  PHC  services  as  external  funding 
support is being phased out. 
(iii)  Develop a detailed budget for the second UPHCP. 
(iv)  Prepare an economic analysis and financial sustainability assessment according 
to ADB’s Handbook for the Economic Analysis of Health Projects.        
 
4.   Sociologist (2 person-months) 
 
4.  The sociologist (or medical anthropologist) will have had at least 8 years of experience in 
the health and nutrition sector, and in resettlement issues. The consultant will facilitate the 
participatory planning process, and ensure that the views and conditions of beneficiaries are 
incorporated in the project design. The consultant will be responsible for the following: 
 
(i)  Arrange  participatory  implementation  of  the  technical  assistance  through 
consultations,  workshops,  and  group  discussions,  involving  all  stakeholders. 
Ensure  that  all  concepts  are  adequately  discussed,  and  that  the  needs  of 
women, children, and other vulnerable groups have been addressed.

Appendix 4  11 
(ii)  Conduct focus group discussions and in-depth interviews of residents of the 
project areas (especially the very poor living in slums and squatter areas, as well 
as the floating population) and staff to determine perceptions of the quality, 
accessibility, and affordability of health services. Identify the services they feel 
are priorities.  
(iii)  Examine what approaches could be used to improve access of the very poor 
(especially  slum-dwellers,  informal  settlers,  and  members  of  the  floating 
population) to services provided by NGOs in partnership areas.  
(iv)  Assess the situation among the very poor, and in discussions with poor families 
and with NGO staff, determine the most effective ways to encourage families so 
that more children and men attend NGO PHC clinics. 
(v)  Describe  beneficiaries’  perceptions  and  practices  regarding  hygiene,  child 
nutrition,  and  health  care,  as  a  basis  for  identifying  interventions.  Include  a 
discussion of how they can work together to improve their environment, including 
better access to clean water, better sanitation, and getting rid of garbage.  
(vi)  Determine strategies whereby communities can identify poor women (living in 
slums, squatter areas, and among the floating population) who can become 
community health workers and how NGOs can work with communities most 
effectively, maximizing community participation. 
(vii)  Prepare a social analysis according to ADB guidelines. 
 
5.      Nutrition Specialist (2 person-months) 
 
5.  The  nutrition  specialist  will  be  a  public  nutrition  specialist  with  at  least  8  years  of 
experience in planning and evaluating nutrition programs and related health services. The 
specialist will develop a package of feasible nutrition and related interventions of proven cost-
effectiveness as part of the contract of services. The consultant will have the following specific 
responsibilities: 
 
(i)  Liaise with stakeholders working in maternal and child nutrition and related health 
care.  
(ii)  Review  the  policy  framework  and  guidelines  for  improving  nutrition  in  urban 
areas in Bangladesh. 
(iii)  Collect and collate information on ongoing nutrition programs and assess current 
services in public and private sectors through field visits to determine “good 
practices,” based on the package of six essential nutrition actions; 
(iv)  Review and discuss with staff and women current nutrition and child health care 
practices at home and in health centers.  
(v)  Propose  a  package  of  nutrition  and  health  interventions  to  be  built  into  the 
contracts for the second UPHCP, and identify and prepare the implementation 
plan including for coordination, related policy actions, and capacity building.  
(vi)  Prepare a written report in response to these TOR. 
 
6.    Capacity-Building Specialist (3 person-months)   
 
6.  The  capacity-building  specialist  will  have  had  at  least  8  years  of  experience  in 
institutional development and training in the public sector, and with the governance specialist, 
will prepare a plan for capacity building of CCs, municipalities, and LGD to develop PHC within 
their jurisdictions.  The consultant will have the following responsibilities:

12  Appendix 4 
(i)  Assess the capabilities of CCs, selected municipalities, LGD, MHFW, and NGOs 
in  health  management,  including  planning,  monitoring,  evaluation,  quality 
assurance, and use of data for decision-making. 
(ii)  Develop a capacity-building plan, including training, use of technical advisers, 
and other inputs.  
(iii)  Visit  CCs  and  selected  municipalities  to  determine  which  ones  can  make  a 
serious commitment to developing their capacity in health management. 
(iv)  Identify key governance issues and propose appropriate arrangements under the 
second UPHCP so that local governance is supported and strengthened in every 
way possible. 
(v)  Assess the experience with performance-based contracting in the UPHCP and 
determine what changes/improvements should be made for the second phase of 
the project. 
(vi)  Prepare a written report in response to these TOR. 
 
7.     Infrastructure Planner (3 person-months) 
 
7.  The infrastructure planner will be an architect or engineer with experience in water and 
sanitation  services,  and  will  focus  on  preparing  an  infrastructure  development  and 
environmental improvement plan for the second phase of the UPHCP.  The consultant will have 
the following specific responsibilities: 
 
(i)  Assess  a  sample  of  the  163  health  facilities  and  satellite  clinics  under  the 
UPHCP to identify ways of improving the site location, design, and use.   
(ii)  Assess environmental health problems and propose ways in which drinking water 
supply, sanitation, and garbage collection can be improved without getting into 
administrative issues. Prepare the environmental assessment and plan.  
(iii)  Conduct health zoning in identified CCs and municipalities to identify locations for 
new services.  
(iv)  Review  the  whole  process  whereby  land  is  obtained  for  constructing  health 
facilities and recommend how to improve the process.  
(v)  Identify any resettlement issues with the help of the sociologist. 
(vi)  Determine options for the second UPHCP, including buying existing buildings, 
renovating them, or purchasing land for new construction.  
(vii)  Develop  architectural  sketch  plans,  specifications,  and  cost  estimates  of  a 
revised health facility design, maximizing input from current users. 
(viii)  Describe  the  annual  maintenance  needs  of  the  recommended  facilities  and 
propose a maintenance plan.  
(ix)  Develop TOR for the professional services needed to construct the civil works 
and improve slum conditions under the second phase of UPHCP.  
(x)  Prepare a written report in response to these TOR.
